Award.AwardTitle: IDR/Collaborative Research: Magnetic Beads Linked Immunoassay Meets Micro Coulter Counter: Novel Multiplexed Biosensor System for Food Safety

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Interdisciplinary Research (IDR) collaborative project is to research a novel tool/device for rapid, sensitive, and simultaneous detection of major pathogenic bacteria in foods. The approach taken will be magnetic beads-linked immunoassays combined with micro coulter counting technique to achieve simultaneous detection of multiple pathogenic bacteria in foods with high specificity and sensitivity. A number of novel features across bio-, micro-, and sensing technologies are introduced to the proposed system. Specifically this proposal will develop a simple and practical sensor for detecting the most significant food-borne pathogens in the United States (eg. Salmonella, Campylobacter and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H7) in chicken and ground beef. The project's method, once optimized, can potentially be applied for detecting a wide range of other targets such as viruses, toxins, and disease-related biomarkers.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include improved food and water safety, which will lead to efficient monitoring and implementation of homeland security, and enhanced public health. In addition, the proposed project offers a truly multidisciplinary training ground for the undergraduate and graduate students involved in the research. The multidisciplinary nature of the research lends itself to dissemination of information in technical as well as non-technical journals and through outreach activities. The award includes year-round undergraduate research projects, utilizing the NSF REU supplement program, UConn's School of Engineering's Da Vinci project (a project geared toward the integration of basic engineering concepts into the post-elementary school classroom), UConn's E2K program to enhance K-12 education, UMass-Lowell's Women in Sciences and Engineering program to uplift the involvement of female minority students, and activities in Homeschoolers Day.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The microbiological safety of foods is a major concern to consumers and to the food industry. During the last decade, food safety received considerable attention due to the emergence of several new food-borne pathogens and the involvement of foods that traditionally have been considered safe, in many food-borne disease outbreaks. This research focuses on the development of a microfluidic-based particle detection system, which is part of a collaborative research between University of Connecticut (UConn) and university of Massachusetts Lowell (UML) aiming to develop an integrated multiplexed biosensor system for applications such as food safety, public health, water quality control, and homeland security.

 The pathogenic bacteria from the solution of contaminated food will be captured onto the antibody-functionalized magnetic beads. These magnetic beads will be suspended into a small volume of electrolyte solution after magnetic washing step, which is subjected to micro counting device. Single particle passing through the two inner electrodes in microfluidic channel will generate a unique pulse electric signal due to the resistance change between the two inner electrodes caused by the presence of the particle. One pulse is corresponding to one particle. The number of pulses can be conveniently correlated to the number (or concentration) of the bacteria in the food. A Lab-on-a-chip (LOC) particle detection system was designed, fabricated and tested in this research. This system can achieve not only the particle counting function but also particle focusing and separation. A computational study was performed to obtain a full understanding of the working mechanisms of particle separation under dielectrophoretic (DEP) force and particle counting in microchannels. An effective separation and counting of yeast cells in a mixture of beads and cells has been achieved using the microfluidic-based particle detection system. The results from this research have built a solid foundation for the development of a biosensor system, featured by rapid diagnosis, ultra-sensitivity, high specificity, easy-to-use, good accessibility, and cost-effectiveness for food-borne pathogens detection.

 The proposed project offers a truly multidisciplinary training ground for under­graduate and graduate students. Five graduates (one graduate student is from UConn) and four undergraduates have been trained on advanced fabrication techniques for LOC system. The results from this research have been published in the refereed journals.  PIs also reached out to local community and make them aware of this research by organizing a group of students from Lawrence Family Development Charter School at Massachusetts (MA) to visit PI’s lab and to learn softlithography technique for fabricating microfluidic devices. PI also actively involved female undergraduate student and minority into this project.
